A optimization algorithm used to minimize the loss function by iteratively adjusting model parameters.
The balance between a model's ability to minimize bias (error from overly simplistic models) and variance (error from overly complex models).
Techniques used to prevent overfitting by adding a penalty to the loss function for large coefficients.
A technique that combines multiple models to improve overall performance such as bagging and boosting.
A function that measures how well the model's predictions match the actual data used to guide optimization.
A supervised learning algorithm that finds the hyperplane that best separates different classes in the data.
A model that uses a tree-like graph of decisions and their possible consequences including chance event outcomes.
An unsupervised learning technique that groups similar data points together based on their features.
A dimensionality reduction technique that transforms data to a new coordinate system reducing complexity while retaining variance.
The process of selecting a subset of relevant features for model building to improve performance and reduce overfitting.
A subfield of NLP focused on generating human-like text from structured data or models.
The process of breaking text into smaller units such as words or phrases for analysis in NLP tasks.
A representation of text data that describes the occurrence of words within a document disregarding grammar and order.
A type of neural network designed for sequential data allowing information to persist across time steps.
A class of deep learning models primarily used for image processing but also applicable to text data.
The process of optimizing the hyperparameters of a model to achieve better performance.
The parameter that controls how much to change the model in response to the estimated error each time the model weights are updated.
A technique to improve the speed performance and stability of artificial neural networks by normalizing the inputs to each layer.
A method where a model developed for one task is reused as the starting point for a model on a second task.
A technique used to increase the diversity of training data by applying random transformations to the original data.
A popular unsupervised learning algorithm that partitions data into K distinct clusters based on feature similarity.
A phenomenon where the feature space becomes increasingly sparse as the number of dimensions increases making data analysis more difficult.
The ratio of true positive predictions to the total predicted positives indicating the accuracy of positive predictions.
The ratio of true positive predictions to the total actual positives measuring the ability of a model to identify all relevant instances.
A measure that combines precision and recall into a single score to evaluate model performance particularly in imbalanced datasets.
A method of converting categorical variables into a binary matrix representation making them suitable for machine learning models.
A type of word representation that allows words to be represented as vectors in a continuous vector space capturing semantic meanings.
A technique used in neural networks to improve performance by focusing on specific parts of the input data rather than processing all input equally.
A specialized type of recurrent neural network capable of learning long-term dependencies in sequence prediction problems.
Capabilities learned in one context that can be applied to another context particularly relevant in multi-task learning scenarios.
A type of neural network used for unsupervised learning that aims to learn efficient representations of data often for dimensionality reduction.
An observation that lies an abnormal distance from other values in a dataset often indicating variability in measurement or experimental errors.
The process of using domain knowledge to create features that make machine learning algorithms work better.
A class of machine learning frameworks where two neural networks contest with each other to generate new data instances.
The condition of having many zero or near-zero values in a dataset which can complicate analysis and modeling.
A loss function commonly used in classification problems that measures the difference between two probability distributions.
A subset of the dataset used to provide an unbiased evaluation of a model during training separate from the training set.
A technique used to determine the significance of individual features in predicting the target variable.
The phenomenon where a model learns the training data too well capturing noise instead of the underlying pattern leading to poor performance on unseen data.
A situation in which a model is too simplistic to capture the underlying trend of the data resulting in poor performance.
A technique that combines predictions from multiple models to improve accuracy and robustness.
An area of machine learning focused on how agents ought to take actions in an environment to maximize cumulative reward.
A field of artificial intelligence that focuses on the interaction between computers and humans through natural language.
A machine learning technique for regression and classification problems that builds models in a stage-wise fashion by optimizing a loss function.
A situation where the model has access to information it shouldn't during training leading to overoptimistic performance estimates.
The process of analyzing data sets to summarize their main characteristics often using visual methods.
An extension of support vector machines to regression problems aiming to find a function that approximates the relationship between variables.
